Accident Prevention Measures
The Accidental Release Prevention Program Executive Summary included in the Risk Management Plan describes the management system in place to ensure safe operation of gas plant processes. The following summarizes the existing safety features which are detailed in the Risk Management Plan.
	The plant encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention.
	The plant keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes.
	The plant has procedures in place to ensure that contractors perform their work in a safe manner, have the appropriate knowledge and skills, are aware of the hazards of their workplace, understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, understand, and follow site safety rules, and inform plant personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.
	The plant has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.
	The plant promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar i

GENERAL DUTY
Prevention of Accidental Release
Background
The Chemical Accidental Release Prevention Provisions are contained in 40 CFR Part 68. The regulation establishes requirements for a stationary source that has more than the threshold quantity of a listed flammable or toxic substance in a process or storage. Sources having less than the threshold quantity of a listed substance, or any quantity of a non-listed, extremely hazardous substance, are subject to the general duty requirements of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990. The June 20, 1996, edition of the Federal Register states the following on page 31670.
...The general duty clause provides that owners and operators have a general duty to identify hazards that may result from accidental releases, design and maintain a safe facility, and minimize the consequences of any releases that occur. The general duty clause is a self-executing statutory requirement: it requires no regulations or other EPA action to take effect. The clause provides a separate statutory mechanism that EPA will use in appropriate circumstances to ensure the protection of public health and the environment.

The general duty clause provides that owners and operators have a general duty to identify hazards that may result from accidental releases, design, and maintain a safe facility, and minimize the consequences of any releases that occur. ACCIDENT HISTORY
According to 40 CFR 68.42, The owner or operator shall include in the five-year accident 
history all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.
The Stationary Source has not had any accidental releases during the past five years that meet the criteria for an accidental release as discussed in 40 CFR 68.42.

VERIFICATION OF PROCESS INFORMATION
Stationary Sources have an ongoing responsibility to monitor whether changes to any process or to the quantities stored or handled alter the facilitys program level eligibility. A 5-year renewal also gives Energy Transfer L.P. personnel the opportunity to verify that each covered process still meets the eligibility criteria for its program level. Based on information regarding the type and quantity of stored/handled chemicals currently onsite, it was verified that the Stationary Source process areas are Program 3 processes under the ARP Program (40 CFR 68).

REVIEW OF EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The Stationary Source is designated as a first responder in case of an accidental release of a regulated substance. The facility maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidently released. If facility employees take part in responding to accidental releases, then the Stationary Source is required to periodically review and update, as appropriate, the facilitys emergency response program and notify employees of any changes to the emergency response plan (40 CFR 68.95). Each covered process regulated under the ARP Program is assigned as either a Program 1, 2, or 3 status and must meet the applicable criteria of the assigned program. Program 1 processes are those that meet the following criteria:
·	the process has not had an accidental release in the past five years that resulted in an offsite consequence (i.e., injuries, deaths, or environmental damage);
·	the distance to an endpoint is less than the distance to any public receptor; and
·	Emergency response has been coordinated with local emergency response organizations.
Program 3 processes meet the following criteria:
·	the distance to an endpoint exceeds the distance to any public receptor; or
·	the process has had an accidental release in the past five years resulting in an offsite consequence; and either
·	Falls into one of ten NAICS codes [32211, 31411, 32511, 325181, 325188, 325192, 325199, 325211, 325311, and 32532]; or subject to the OSHA process safety management standard [40 CFR 68.10 (d) (2)].
Program 2 processes are those that do not meet Program 1 or 3 criteria.
